bibl.title: Letter from A. S. Pinto to Albert E. Truby, September 19, 1941

div1.p: Pinto remarks that Truby's manuscript is a nice contribution to yellow fever history. He congratulations Truby on becoming a grandpa and discusses his own family.

div1.head: Letter from A. S. Pinto to Albert E. Truby, September 19, 1941
div1.opener:
A. GREENBERG, M. D.
DEPUTY HEALTH COMMISSIONER
N. H. ATTWOOD, M. D.
CHIEF POLICE SURGEON
CITY OF OMAHA
HEALTH DEPARTMENT
OMAHA, NEB.
-----
A. S. PINTO, M. D.
HEALTH COMMISSIONER
F. E. COLIE
DIRECTO
BRUCE R. F.
ASSISTA
Omaha, Nebr.
Sept 19, 1941
General A. E. Truby,
145 Laurel Str.,
San Francisco, Calif.
My dear Mr. (True):
div1.p:
I had a chance to finish my suggestions on your manuscript, and I
am returning it to you by mail. In my opinion that is one of the nicest
contributions to the yellow-fever history that I have ever seen, and I
believe I have read most all that has been written on the subject. Your
description is so clear-cut and so true to form that I do not see how it
could be improved upon, and having been through the seige myself it was
doubly interesting to me. I want to thank you for the kind words which
you have said in it concerning myself.

I now want to congratulate you for being Grandpa for the first time.
I have two sons, both doctors. The younger son Harvey, is in the Agnew
State Hospital, Agnew, California, near San Jose. He is specializing in
psychiatry. It is only 45 miles fron San Francisco and I hope that you
may sometime find it convenient to drop in and see him. He is married
and has four children, two boys and two girls and as nice a family as you
will ever see any place. He is of a very pleasant disposition, was marrie[d]
young only twenty years of age, and his wife a very charming lady and as
nice a mother as it is anyone's good fortune to meet.

The older boy Sherman Has two children Boy & girl is with the Massachusetts State Board of Health
as an Industrial Hygienist. He secured this position after having taken a
Public Health Course at Harvard. He is very much in love with his work and
I think will make a success of it. He spent a year and a half at Walter
Reed Hospital and I think while you were in Washington, and I did not know
it at that time or I would have had him look you up. He was under Dr.
Metcalfe who was in charge of the surgery at that time, and who by the wa[y]
I was associated with in the P.I's. These are the only two children I ha[ve]
and there is only seventeen months difference in their ages.

I hope to be in California some time this fall, and if I get out the[re]
I assure you that I will look up my old pal. Thanking you very much for
allowing me to read your manuscript and assuring you of the continuation
of my good wishes in all your endeavors, I am as ever your friend,
